properties.DESCRIPTION: Over the past thirty years, the lowest-lying areas of some fields here have become too wet to farm due to rising water levels.
Freshwater species have been dying out over the past 10-15 years as the water becomes increasingly brackish.
Pitts Creek Landing parking lot is now often flooded on high tides, and the dock had to be raised.

This area was once extensively farmed, and dikes are still in place that were used to hold back the rising water. Cattle and hogs grazed here on Spartina Patens (marsh hay), and the foundation of the old house can still be seen.
Cattle were grazed here on Spartina Patens (marsh hay). It is a marsh now.
Cattle grazed here on Spartina Patens (marsh hay) up until the mid-twentieth century. This is marsh now.
The area here was once referred to as Piney Hummock. It no longer exists as such and is now a marsh.

Belinda was a village that was virtually abandoned, probably in the 1930s, mostly due to rising water levels. People could no longer grow vegetable gardens to locally support their families and relocated to the higher elevations at Sanford Ridge.
Marsh Market was a village that was once located here but was virtually abandoned in the early 20th century due to rising water levels The ground became "too wet to have a garden".
Messongo was a village that was once located here but was virtually abandoned due to rising water levels and relocation of the steamboat to Saxis in the early 20th century.
People moved to the Sanford Ridge area from the communities of Belinda, Marsh Market and Messongo when the inundation of these lower-lying communities became too frequent.
Fields were abandoned here due to higher water levels.
The woods here are moving back from all the creeks in this area.
Dikes here illustrate that efforts were made to keep the water away before the area was no longer viable for farming.
This whole area was once farmed but is mostly marsh now and too wet to farm.  The only  remaining evidence of the land's former use is a beautiful pear tree.
Many roads now flood frequently at low points such as Jenkins Bridge. High winds and tides often result in brackish water being pushed up onto roads.
In the 1930s, this area was used to raise strawberries by Bradford Hall. It is marsh now.

This was the Martin Family's "Old Place." They trapped about 4,000 muskrats per year. One of the original sheds still stands. The Finney family also trapped muskrats there, but the area is no longer used.
The Oyster House located in the area next to the causeway just before entering the town now floods regularly at high tide.
The forest south of the causeway has gotten thinner and thinner over the past five years.
The land on both sides of Hummock Road became so wet that people moved away.
Ellsworth Linton lived here in the 1950s and 1960s, but it now floods regularly, and no one lives there now.
Hurricane Sandy put water in the house here for the first timein the structure's history.
Ellsworth lived in this house until 1930. It was then high enough to have a garden but is now wet all the time.
The main road in Saxis was raised in 1978, so it doesn't flood as much as it had previously. However, the land around it is now wet all the time.
This land was all previously farmed, but it is too wet now.
The steamboat regularly docked at Marsh Market until the late 19th century. The creek was getting shallow, so when Saxis built a steamboard pier, the boat no longer went to Marsh Market.
The Fletcher Homestead house was dissassembled by the family and moved to the York River sometime in the 20th century.
Flag Pond Road is frequently flooded now.
This area has eroded so that the foundation of an old house is out in the water.
Up until the late 1600s, this whole area was farmland and is now mostly marsh.

The water level here was probably 3 feet lower here in the colonial period. This area was farmed, a house stood near the point, and its foundation is now underwater.  Also, the drainage ditches here and many other places on the Eastern Shore have not been maintained and are plugged up so that water stands in them for weeks. This causes increased flooding on the roads.
There were three brackish ponds here up until 25 years ago when the surrounding uplands eroded.
There were still two brackish ponds on this island until 15 years ago the surrounding uplands eroded away and the bay broke through. This area is now a low muddy flat crying to be vegetated.

Mockhorn Island once had extensive uplands but now is predominantly marsh with some small remaining hummocks. There are two abandoned range towers whose bases are now in the water. When these were built, the area was an upland.

There was a working farm here with 17 tillable acres. It was diked with earth with a canal on inside and a concrete seawall. There were cattle on the land until storms came and went over the dike and flooded the whole place. The cedar and pine trees disappeared in the 1950s.
Almost every house here has been raised up on pilings because of flooding. Flooding did not occur as frequently as it now does when these homes were originally constructed.
The marsh over which the causeway passes was once high but is now reverting to mud flats.
Franklin City began fading in the 1960s with construction of the Chincoteague Causeway. Many of these now vacant lots have uplands that have since converted to tidal marsh.

This area has experienced the gradual decline of a stand of seven mature loblolly pines due to rising water levels and saltwater intrusion. In 1987, there were five remaining; in 1998 three remained, and in 2011 all were dead.
